item.description: .  You can trade crypto futures via:Chicago Mercantile ExchangeBakktCrypto stocksThere are several cryptocurrency companies with publicly-traded shares that you can get your hands on. Ethereum ultimately powers a network of decentralized crypto businesses that everyone can use and nobody can take down. Choose your cryptocurrencyThe two titansTwo cryptos stand head and shoulders over the rest, representing nearly 70% of the total industry: Bitcoin and Ether.  But in a world being eaten alive by software, the allure of grabbing some digital gold amid the rush is undeniable.  Bitcoin (BTC)Created in 2009, Bitcoin is the oldest cryptocurrency and maintains a dominant market share of about half the market.

item.title: The Biggest Changes To the Post-Pandemic Workplace Will Be Invisible
item.description: If we look at a) Sydney, Australia, and Nottingham, UK, which have intermittently resumed office work and b) US companies’ latest plans for post-pandemic office space, it’s clear most workplaces will look more like futuristic WeWorks than Mr. Nobody’s White Room. offices will likely have stricter (and more obvious) protocols when employees first return, and like what’s currently happening in Australia, they may have to toggle back and forth between fully open and shut down until Covid-19 flare-ups are under control. Google's blog shows off Camp CharlestonThe other way offices will get more fresh air to employees? Bottom line: From air filtration to green spaces, the office transformations discussed so far will be implemented to make employees feel—and actually be—safer from the spread of disease, especially Covid-19, while working at the office. Other changes will focus on accommodating newly hybrid workforcesMany workers who’ve spent the past 1+ years cooking elaborate breakfasts aren’t ready to return to microwaved oatmeal: 30% of employees would seek out a different job if their companies returned to fully in-office work following the pandemic, per a Mckinsey survey. but not so much that employees will have to battle for workspaces like they’re going full seagull on each other for kettle chips. It’s when employees “rent” a desk for the day, or hours at a time, and share it with other coworkers when they’re OOO. It depends on how many days each employee swipes in, which will vary by workplace. At Adtrak, employees will book their desks in advance through an app.

item.title: The new office politics? An ‘existential crisis’ for some
item.description: Lat speaks about a law firm that recently decreed employees must return to the office five days a week, only to be met with staff reaching out en masse to recruiters for jobs elsewhere. You may have heard of this described as the “hybrid” work environment, where some people work from home and others log on from a corporate office. The idea that office politics are winnable? “That might not be a bad thing because there are a lot of artificial deadlines of, ‘I want this on my desk first thing in the morning’ by bosses who, lo and behold, don’t read that until the afternoon or the next day,” he says.  The shift to a virtual workplace was hard on office politics, too, particularly in hidebound industries like finance and law where remote work was relatively rare before the pandemic. For example, some workers are easing their sense of urgency around work projects, Lat notes, because it proved to be a charade all along. What I’ve seen and heard from workers is that now, when a manager steps in, they’re actually getting in the way of work.” “The invisible work women have always done is finally being recognized and appreciated because men had to experience it,” says Dawn Bovasso, a freelance creative director in Boston who has written about workplace policies’ effects on women. “The old way was really exclusive, excluding a lot of people: people of color, women, the differently abled—a lot of people,” she says.  If the performative politics of pre-pandemic office life are a bowl of ice cream, the pandemic surely melted it. “This new way is going to be inclusive. If the corporate world’s reaction to the COVID-19 pandemic turned 2020 into a mad scramble for new protocols defined by adaptive office tools like Google Docs, Slack, and Zoom, then its adjustment to a tentative recovery suggests a partial return to the office and semi normalcy. “A lot of office politics is over stupid stuff and a lot of that stupid stuff is tied to the physical environment: fighting over the corner office, talking so loudly on calls that coworkers can hear them down the hall, being bad at bathroom etiquette, vaping at your desk, leaving smelly food in the break room,” he says. The virtual environment has undoubtedly given workers more power over their supervisors. “It is challenging to replicate office politics in a virtual era, which isn’t a bad thing,” says David Lat, a longtime analyst of law firm culture and himself a former top-tier recruiter. “So much of politics arises from physical interaction, so if we have less interaction we have less cause for conflict and less need for politics.” True, the completely virtual environment that many people have been working in for 17 months has hardly been a cakewalk.
